description.narrative:
The proposed programme ultimately aims to reduce unemployment and boost livelihood amongst young women and men from poorer families through strengthening gender responsive governance, quality and relevance of the TVET system in South Sudan. This includes strengthening environment and climate change awareness and adaptation capacity to reduce vulnerability and incident of conflict.
The planned impact is: "Better governance and TVET provision in South Sudan leading to improved livelihoods of young women and men."
Outcome 1: National inclusive TVET governance structures and evidence-based policies foster youth employment in South Sudan aims at strengthening TVET governance and equip key actors with sustainable capacities and tools to develop evidence-based policies and the related legal framework, while mobilizing private sector involvement in TVET governance.
Outcome 2: National TVET institutions, techers and trainers are better equipped to provide quality, gender-transformative and green TVET programmes intends to improve the quality of TVET provision. This will be accomplished by reinforcing national capacities and institutions in charge of TVET teachers training design and implementation as well those responsible for TVET curricula development, adopting a gender transformative and green lens.
Outcome 3: Young women and men in South Sudan have improved access to labour market and climate change responsive TVET opportunities. This outcome aims at helping TVET institutions develop labour market-responsive TVET, work-based learning and internship opportunities in conflict-affected remote locations through the provision of mobile TVET, micro-entrepreneurship skills programmes and private-public partnerships at institution level.

UNESCO har ansökt om 100 000 000 SEK för implementering av programmet "Strengthening Technical and Vocational Education and Training in South Sudan" under perioden 2021-2025 i Sydsudan.
Programmet syftar till att stärka Sydsudans yrkesutbildningssystem. Programmet ämnar bidra framför allt till SDG 4, 5, 8 och 13 genom att uppnå resultat inom tre målområden. I målområde ett är syftet att etablera och stärka en inkluderande styrning av Technical and Vocational Education and Training (TVET) där den privata sektorn ska vara delaktig. Ett yrkesutbildningssystem som svarar mot behoven på arbetsmarknaden förväntas leda till bättre utbildad arbetskraft, ökat antal arbetstillfällen och främjandet av en sundare arbetsmiljö. Under målområde två är syftet att stärka nationella utbildningsinstitutioner genom vidareutbildning av yrkesutbildningslärare, utveckling av läroplaner, utbildnings- och lärmaterial med genderperspektiv och miljö- och klimatperspektiv. Under målområde tre är målet att ungdomar som står utanför skolan ska få tillgång till yrkesutbildning och baskunskaper inom läs- och skrivkunnighet.
Sida är den enda finansiären av programmet som ska implementeras av UNESCO tillsammans med utvalda implementerande partners.

UNESCO has applied for 100 000 000 SEK from Sida to the programme "Strenghtening Technical and Vocational Education and Training in South Sudan", during the period 2021-2025.
The programme aims at strengthening the technical and vocational education and training in South Sudan. The programme specifically contributes to SDG 4, 5, 8 and 13 by aiming at reaching results in three outcomes. Under outcome one the programme aims at establish and strengthen an inclusive TVET governance mechanism in the country with active participation and engagement of the private sector in the TVET governance body. Consequently, a TVET system that responds to the needs of the labour market will lead to skilled human resources, job growth and promote a decent work environment. Under outcome two national TVET institutes will be better equipped to deliver TVET by strengthening the training of TVET teachers, reviewing and developing gender-aware curricula and teaching/learning materials. Under outcome three out of school youth will have access to TVET including functional literacy skills. All three outcomes contributes to SDG 5 on gender equality.
Sida is the only funder of programme which will be implemented by UNESCO together with selected implementing partners.

title.narrative: Agreement between UNESCO and Sida South Suda contribution 13462

description.narrative:
Sida assesses that the project objectives are clear and realistic to acheive across all levels; national policy level, mid-stream level with TVET centres, and community level with the mobile TVET programme. Further, the objectives are deemed to be achievable within the given time frame, budget, and locations. The inception phase will allow for fine-tuning of the activities under the objectives, guided by the analysis to take place.
Sida assesses that the Theory of Change is well thought out and the logic chain is clear, sufficiently guiding the project implementation. The risks are clearly spelt out in the proposal, as well as the mitigation measures. The assumptions are well defined, albeit a couple of them are facing considerable risks.
The proposal outlines a participatory and inclusive approach. All relevant stakeholders and beneficiaries will be directly engaged in developing policies and frameworks and implementing interventions that directly concern them. The implementation will be done in close coordination and collaboration with the government under the leadership of the MoGEI and through the government training centres, which will lead to the ownership of the respective ministries towards the programme. The project will adopt a partnership approach to implement downstream activities through the local partners who are already established in the selected project locations. This approach will ensure ownership of the outputs of the project. Sida assesses that UNESCO has planned sufficiently to ensure ownership of the programme from the local level to the national level.
Most of the outputs from the project will continue to be functional under the leadership of the TVET Body of Authority and TVET Working Group at the national and state level, underpinning sustainability beyond the project durations. The curriculum and training manuals will be adopted by MoGEI and used by all TVET implementers as national harmonized curricula. Likewise, the engagement of key stakeholders in designing, implementation and monitoring of the activities under this project, will allow for the model to be adopted, replicated and expanded within the country based on lessons learned. For sustainability of TVET centres and funtion of Body of Authority, the project will pay special attention to resource mobilisation by engaging private sector in the governance structure and supporting TVET centres for setting up cost recovery measures.
While the ownership and other factors mentioned above underpins the sustainability of results from the project, there are also components which imposes risk to the sustainability. One of those risks is inadequate finance contribution from the government, ranked as a high risk in UNESCO´s risk analysis. This stems from the fact that the annual budget allocated by the Government of South Sudan for the education sector is very low. For the period 2019-2020, the total budget allocated for the MoGEI, Ministry of Higher Education, Science and Technology (MoHEST) and National Examination Council (NEC) was only 5.55% of the total budget, with TVET receiving only a fraction. Further, TVET centres have faced challenges in terms of maintenance and payment of tutors. It has mostly been INGOs and donors that have kept the centres working - and not all of them are functioning. As such, unless there is a central, systematic way to support TVET centres and to ensure instructors are paid, there is a risk that the centres will not survive long after project closure.To mitigate these risks, UNESCO through the Project Advisory Committee, legislative committees overseeing ministries and TVET Working Group will continue to lobby and advocate with the Ministry of Finance and Planning to increase total allocation for education and particularly for TVET to meet the minimum requirement. The project will also work with resource mobilization to ensure cost sharing from different actors, including private sector. A resource mobilization sub-committe has already been formed under the national TVET Coordination Committee. Sida also has the ambition to support and strengthen the possibilities for increased sustainability, for example through advocating for more funding for the TVET sector together with other donors and key actors.
It is Sida's assessment that sustainability measures have been adequately put in place to the extent possible, but that the risks goes beyond the control of UNESCO and the project.
